txt.en: 'Is it time to eat yet?'
'Be silent, Carus.'
'Ahem.'
'The Elder will come out to speak soon.'
Clansman
'What a boring night this always proves to be.'
'This is always such a boring night.'
'Oh, it is not, Ithel! Hush.'
'Ah, we made it. At least we did not walk all that way for naught.'
'Ah, the mountain-folk have arrived.'
'But where is the family from the southern farm? They are missing....'
'How long will the Elder ramble on before the feast starts?'
'My old eyes no longer see well.'
'And bored.'
'This horse-tail is for Rohan, the land of usurpers.'
'The Horse-lords are our bitter enemies, and they drove us from our rightful lands.'
'Someday, the lands must belong to the Dunlendings again.'
'Never, ever forget our rightful home.'
'And one last favour, [placeholder]. The spear.'
'Ah, poor Elder. This part of the ritual always rouses his sadness.'
'This is a spear of the Dragon-clan.'
'It slew my son, who should have been a leader after me.'
'Honoured guest, will you fetch me the ritual crown? It is at my door.'
'Thank you, [placeholder].'
'Why I make this trek every year, I will never know.'
'Ah, here it is. Thank you again.'
'Thank you, kind one.'
'This crown is for the kingdom... for the king that has forsaken Dunland.'
'It is for the children of this land who have been abandoned by Gondor.'
'Never forget the king whose laws forsook us...'
'...For we are free. Forsaken and free.'
'[placeholder], will you fetch me the horse-tail now?'
Clanswoman
'Oh dear, [placeholder]....'
'You see, Grandfather? There are more pressing matters than festivals.'
'Yes, I will be there! Just like every year. But it is a very boring event.'
'When you are chief, Guto, you will be free to ignore all the festivals you like.'
'We only go to humour the Elder, you know.'
'But as far as I can tell, I am not yet dead!'
'These old rites have no point anymore! Why do we not just forget them?'
'So until I am, you will show respect for our traditions.'
'Yes, yes. I will go. Do not nag me!'
'I am sorry, my people, but there might be some danger to the south. I am calling an early end to the Festival.'
'Just be sure to wake me when it is time to eat. Ha!'
'You may take food from the feast and return to your huts for now....'
'I will certainly be there tonight, dear friend!'
'Go humour my grandfather somewhere else; you waste your words on me.'
Clansman
'Awk!'
'Caw!'
'Look! There is Guto. I knew he would come.'
'My grandson's father's blood still stains its tip.'
'With this spear, we remember that our own people have turned on us.'
'We remember that Dunland is not one people with a common cause.'
'We remember that our own brother clans chased us to the edge of Dunland...'
'...Where we settled in peace in Trum Dreng, the land that nobody wanted.'
'Never forget how we came here, even though you were not born to witness it.'
'Grandfather.'
'What is it, Guto?'
'Grandfather, a crow has returned, but it is injured.'
'...But I have seen to it that the Dragon-clan will trouble you no more.'
'He speaks true, grandfather!'
'He slew the Dragon-clan chieftain for his crime of disobedience, right before my eyes!'
'I see.'
'What then is your offer, just duvodiad?'
'That the Stag-clan should join forces with the White Hand...'
'...And under Saruman's banner, the peoples of Dunland will be united.'
'And together, we shall march against your foes of old: the Horse-lords!'
'But... why would Isengard wish to wage war against Rohan?'
'Yes, Elain. Why indeed?'
Clanswoman
Guto
Elder Riag√°n
'What do you make of this, Elder?'
'Nothing yet, my dear. I would like to hear why Guto brings this White Hand fellow to Lhan Tarren.'
'This way, honoured guest.'
'Grandfather, this man of Isengard brings us great news!'
'I do not see a man -- only an Orc. But you have my ear, duvodiad.'
'I come with a message of peace from Saruman of Isengard, the good neighbour of Dunland.'
'As I told Guto, the attacks on Trum Dreng by the Dragon-clan were a terrible misunderstanding....'
'To help you win back your lands, of course. Do you not long to reclaim your rightful home?'
'Ha! Yes, I am sure Saruman wants war to help his dear neighbours, the poor, misplaced Men of Dunland.'
'Saruman is so kind and good... why did we never see it before?'
'...If mockery is all I can expect from the Stag-clan, I will trouble you no more.'
'Good luck with your generous war, well-spoken stranger.'
'You are a fool, grandfather!'
'Hush, Guto! The Elder was wise to turn that wicked man away!'
'Our clan will never be great again! You have squandered this opportunity!'
'Guto! Wait!'
'Oh, Guto. When will you learn?'
'Come now. There is wisdom in these rites.'
Clanswoman
'Elain will probably sleep through it too, ha!'
'The Elder comes. Show some respect!'
'Welcome, my kin, to the Feast of the Running Stag.'
'As many of you know, we gather each year to share our history....'
'It is a sad history.'
'It is a history that none should forget, not until the last of us is dead.'
